supply_logistics.supply_status: Recovering post-campaign. After Axis surrender (13 May 1943), supply situation improved dramatically. Fuel and ammunition no longer prioritized for offensive operations; resupply convoys from Egypt arrived regularly. Food variety improved with captured Axis stocks and local Tunisian procurement. Brigade transitioned to occupation duties with reduced operational tempo. Vehicle maintenance prioritized to rebuild transport fleet degraded by 6-month combat operations (Nov 1942 - May 1943). Morale exceptionally high following Allied victory in North Africa - Greeks celebrated end of North Africa Campaign as major step toward homeland liberation.

tactical_doctrine.role: Free Greek infantry brigade integrated into British 8th Army for final Tunisia Campaign operations. Brigade participated in Battle of Enfidaville (19-21 April 1943), the final major 8th Army offensive in North Africa, and subsequent operations through Axis surrender (13 May 1943). Transitioned to occupation and security duties post-victory. Combat-proven formation with nearly 7 months continuous operations (El Alamein through Tunisia). High morale maintained despite mounting casualties and absence of replacement pipeline. Allied victory in North Africa celebrated as major milestone toward Greek homeland liberation.

Exceptional morale - victory in North Africa seen as step toward Greek liberation

known_issues: Cumulative attrition - 295 casualties from Q1 baseline (9% strength loss)
No replacement pipeline - unit strength declining throughout campaign
Anti-tank weapons obsolescent (2-pounder inadequate vs. heavy German armor)
Vehicle fleet degraded after 7 months operations - maintenance critical
Equipment shortages compared to full British brigade establishment
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Extensive desert adaptation complemented by Tunisian terrain experience. Brigade completed North Africa Campaign with combat experience across full range of North African environments: Western Desert (Egypt, Libya), Tunisian coastal plains, hill country, and wadis. Fully adapted to desert vehicle maintenance, water discipline, navigation, and supply challenges. Tunisian terrain experience gained through 4 months operations (Jan-May 1943).

precise_casualties_final_offensive.reason: Greek Brigade casualty records for final offensive (April-May 1943) provide battle totals but not detailed unit-by-unit breakdowns
precise_casualties_final_offensive.estimate_method: Estimated 295 total casualties from Q1 baseline (3,280 to 2,985 personnel = 9% attrition) during final offensive operations. Distributed across battalions proportionally based on tactical deployment and known engagement intensity (Enfidaville was particularly costly). HQ and support elements estimated based on British casualty patterns from artillery/air attack.

vehicle_losses_final_offensive.reason: Precise vehicle write-offs during final offensive not documented at brigade level
vehicle_losses_final_offensive.estimate_method: Estimated 12 additional truck losses during final offensive (Enfidaville through May 1943) based on combat intensity and terrain challenges. Armored car losses estimated at 1-2 vehicles based on reconnaissance role. Total transport degradation reflects 7 months continuous operations without major replacement.

discovered_units.reason: Elite Greek special forces unit NOT in seed file. Fought separately from 1st Greek Brigade. Attached to Free French forces (Force L / Leclerc) and British SAS operations in Tunisia.
discovered_units.combat_evidence: Sacred Squadron participated in Tunisia Campaign (Feb-Apr 1943) including: Battle of Ksar-Rillan (10 March 1943) covering X Corps advance, Wadi Akarit operations with 2nd New Zealand Division (6 April 1943), entered Sousse (12 April 1943), and Battle of Enfidaville (13-17 April 1943). Unit operated as Light Mechanized Cavalry under French command. Documented combat participation distinct from 1st Greek Brigade operations.
